text: it's it's less about a particular
organization or a
particular activity it's about whether
or not you've given the money in such a
way that you can actually have some
confidence that it's going to make the
change in the world you want and that
change can
be you know having another student risk
of dropping out actually being able to
graduate on time that change could be um
getting a existing coste effective drug
for malaria to a child in time that you
save that person's life um I distinguish
between high impact philanthropy and
other types of philanthropy because some
philanthropy isn't practiced in such a
way that it can assure those kinds of
results um and in fact many
philanthropists don't necessarily give
with the idea of trying to maximize the
social good of their philanthropy so um
for those folks who are giving out of a
sense of
obligation or reciprocal giving my
buddy's on a board um he gave money to
my fundraiser so I gave money to his
fundraiser or um you know I don't care
so much about I'm speaking from the
point of view of philanthropist I don't
care so much about whether or not I am
really maximizing the impact of my gift
but I'm really happy that my name's on
that big building okay so so that's high
impact philanthropy is different from
that kind of um social or reciprocal
philanthropy in that it's squarely
focused on improving the lives of others
all
philanthropy especially high impact
philanthropy where people are really
focusing on
results it starts with a personal
commitment um and so you know this is
it's a personal commitment to making a
change in the world and how people got
to that commitment is a very unique and
personal
journey I don't think you want to
disrupt that Journey because one of the
things with high impact philanthropy is
you have to have a commitment to ongoing
learning there are no silver bullets so
you have to be able to care enough about
the
issue to learn
when you've goofed up and to redirect or
add more resour resources than you
thought you needed in order to achieve
your good and what's exciting is when a
philanthropist says I'm committed to
making a change in this area whatever
that area is once you get to that point
then you say great how can you translate
that commitment and those good
intentions and whatever resources you're
bringing to the table
to actually making the difference you
want to make you know that that's where
hopefully our work plays is to to
translate those good intentions and that
commitment to actual impact
